card.title: How the hot water that fueled Hurricane Beryl foretells a scary storm season
card.description: Hurricane Beryl’s explosive growth into an unprecedented early storm shows the literal hot water the Atlantic and Caribbean are in right now and the kind of season they can expect. Beryl smashed storm records even before its major hurricane level winds approached land. The powerful storm is acting more like the monsters that form at the peak of the busiest hurricane seasons on record — 1933 and 2005. And experts say that's mostly due to water temperatures as hot or hotter than the region normally gets in September.

content:
What #SCOTUS just did to #broadband, the #RightToRepair, the #environment, and more

By overturning Chevron, the Supreme Court has declared war on an administrative state that touches everything from net neutrality to climate change.

By Verge Staff
Jun 28, 2024

"Since the New Deal era, the bulk of the functioning US government is the administrative state — think the acronym soup of agencies like the #EPA, #FCC, #FTC, #FDA, and so on. Even when Capitol Hill is not mired in deep dysfunction, the speed at which Congress and the courts operate no longer seems suitable for modern life. Both industry and ordinary people look to the administrative state, rather than legislators, for an immediate answer to their problems. And since 1984, the administrative state largely ran on one Supreme Court precedent: #ChevronUSA, Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council (#NRDC).

"That decision has now been overturned. Admin law is not always interesting, but the simple fact is when it comes to the day-to-day, agencies are the most impactful part of the federal government. No single policy writer at The Verge can fully articulate the impact of Friday’s Supreme Court decision and how profound its effects will be. The administrative state touches everything around us: net neutrality, climate change, #CleanAir and water, and what scant #ConsumerProtections we have.

"While the practice had been in place for decades before, it came to be known as Chevron deference after a 1984 case: Chevron v. NRDC. The Supreme Court ruled in favor of Chevron, allowing the #RonaldReagan administration’s #industry-friendly Environmental Protection Agency to stick with a lax interpretation of the #CleanAirAct.

"Over the years, Chevron deference has enabled federal agencies to tackle all sorts of issues that legislators have yet to cover — from addressing greenhouse gas emissions causing climate change to regulating broadband access. As the conservative legal movement to disempower the administrative state grew, Chevron deference became — in certain circles — shorthand for #GovernmentOverreach.

"Before its decision to overturn Chevron, the Supreme Court had already dealt a blow to federal agencies’ regulatory authority by strengthening the 'major questions' doctrine in its 2022 decision in West Virginia v. EPA. According to the major questions doctrine, a federal agency shouldn’t have the leeway to craft regulation on an issue of major national significance if Congress hasn’t explicitly allowed it to do so in legislation.

"The same bloc of six #conservative justices that formed the majority in West Virginia v. EPA also overturned the longstanding precedent of #RoeVsWade — an even older case than Chevron — in the same month. When two cases calling for an end to Chevron deference worked their way up to the Supreme Court this year, the writing was on the wall — and once again, those same six justices overturned Chevron.

Impacts:
- #NetNeutrality
- The #environment and efforts to fight #ClimateChange
- Regulating #BigTech
- #TechWorkers on #visas and #immigration law
- #Labor and #WorkersRights
- The right to repair, #copyright, #PatentLaw, and the Apple Watch ban

https://www.theverge.com/24188365/chevron-scotus-net-neutrality-dmca-visa-fcc-ftc-epa

#DMCA #Chevron #PowerGrab #CorporateFascism #ChevronDeference #WaterIsLife #CleanWaterAct #SCOTUS #ScotusIsCorrupt #ScrotusSunday #ImpeachJusticeThomas #ImpeachJusticeAlito #KochBrothers

Beryl, the first hurricane of the 2024 Atlantic season, intensified to an extremely dangerous Category 4 storm with maximum sustained winds of 130 mph Sunday, as it made its way toward the Windward Islands.

Beryl is the earliest Category 4 hurricane on record in the Atlantic Ocean and the only Category 4 storm ever recorded in the month of June.

The early timing of the season’s first hurricane is unusual, given the average date for the first hurricane is August 11.

Forecasters have warned that this hurricane season could be hyperactive – and Beryl’s record-shattering activity may be a sign of what’s to come.
____________________________

Modernizing Probable Maximum Precipitation Estimation

The authors recommend a new definition of Probable Maximum Precipitation and present a vision for a method relevant to the design, operation, and regulation of critical infrastructure. The new definition targets precipitation depths with an extremely low exceedance probability instead of assuming rainfall is bounded and considers specified climate periods.

content:
If you're think of buying a pickup truck or an SUV ask yourself these questions first:

1. Do I really need it? As in, do I have any practical use for one? Do I work a labor-intensive, blue collar job or own a commercial business that would necessitate such a vehicle?

2. I'm a single person with no dependents. Would a truck/SUV be an appropriate vehicle when a hatchback or even a compact sedan would do? Am I better off using interpersonal transportation such a bicycle in conjunction with public transit?

3. I'm a parent with 1 child. Should I buy a truck/SUV when a hatchback or sedan can do much of the same?

4. I'm a parent with 2+ children. Which is more adequate: an impractical, fuel inefficient truck or a spacious, economical station wagon or even a minivan?
#cars #urbanism #climatechange #fuckcars

content:
Every year the world is generating much more electricity from renewables, especially wind power and solar power.

Yay! Good job. Right?

Only sort of. Because this will NOT prevent catastrophic climate and environmental breakdown — unless it is coupled with an overall reduction in total energy output.

We need to slow down, not speed up.
_____________________________

World CO₂ emissions and energy consumption continue to rise. Emissions have increased at twice the rate so far in 2024 as in 2022 or 2023. Current atmospheric CO₂ concentration has increased to 426.9 ppm, up from 421.9 in December 2023.

The problem is that emissions will continue to rise as long as electric power use increases. Despite a four-fold expansion of wind and solar electric power generation by 2050, world carbon emissions are expected to climb because total generation will rise 14 gigawatt hours by then.

It’s time to abandon the fantasy that technology will save us. Technological fixes have consistently failed to deliver on their promises. The only effective course of action is to reduce overall energy consumption.

There is a time for hope, but also a time for honesty. Under the current strategy of international conferences and public spending on wealth transfer schemes disguised as green deals, there is no realistic scenario for successful decarbonization.
_____________________________

If you put on your rose-colored glasses and squint your eyes, it *might* look as if we are making progress. But it is WAY too slow, too little, and too late.

We need #degrowth now.

FULL ARTICLE -- https://www.artberman.com/blog/lets-stop-arguing-about-an-imaginary-energy-transition/

#Science #Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #Capitalism #BusinessAsUsual

media_attachments.description: Graph shows the projected rise in total electrical power generation from 2022 through 2050, as described in post and in linked article. Although solar and wind power generation are expected to grow substantially, fossil fuel use will not decline. A large proportion of electric power generation will still come from coal, oil, and natural gas by 2050.

card.title: Let's Stop Arguing About An Imaginary Energy Transition | Art Berman
card.description: How did adoption of renewable energy become the drug of choice to treat the disease of climate change? No one knows. Wind and solar energy policies evolved over several decades without planning, leadership, effective communication, or stakeholder engagement. There was not---and is not---any vision, resource allocation, communication strategy, governance structure,…

content:
Global climate change and soccer (football) are having a moment in Miami. At #CopaAmérica , unruly fans and/or unprepared staff had to close gates due to crowd rushing and gate crashing. Game time was delayed by almost an hour. Even at 8pm, it was 87°F (31°C), and people had many issues with the heat and the lack of water. Being in the United States, water was only available for purchase (capitalism extracts from all of us).

A good bit of of these spectators arrived by plane and/or large SUV. A tiny minority arrived by public transportation.

Game time delayed 1h15m. That's an extra 75 minutes in that heat.

card.title: Storms flood the Ozarks and strand drivers in Toronto
card.description: Much of the U.S. and Canada is cleaning up or still dealing with a new wave of severe storms that have caused deaths and damage this week from the Plains to New England. Water rescues and evacuations took place in the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas and Missouri on Wednesday after as much as 11 inches of rain fell overnight. A confirmed tornado was strong enough Tuesday to move an old B-52 bomber in Rome, New York. Some buildings in Rome are destroyed and streets are clogged with debris. Flooding left drivers stranded around Toronto. The East Coast from Maine to the Carolinas is being warned of dangerous heat.
card.image_description: Ashley Joiner, 17, uses a squeegee broom to push water out of the fellowship hall at the Christian Church in Flippin, Ark., after it flooded on Wednesday, July 17, 2024. (Staci Vandagriff/Arkansas Democrat-Gazette via AP)

#Derecho turns deadly, #tornado reported near #Chicago's #OHareAirport

A line of powerful thunderstorms hammered the Midwest Monday afternoon into Monday night, leading to at least one fatality as winds howled over 100 mph.

By Brian Lada, AccuWeather meteorologist and staff writer

Published Jul 16, 2024 11:55 AM EDT

"Intense thunderstorms packing wind gusts over 100 mph blasted across the Midwest Monday afternoon into Monday night, snapping trees and damaging buildings during an extreme weather event known as a derecho.

"At least one person was killed amid the storms when a tree fell on a home in Cedar Lake, Indiana, located 35 miles southeast of Chicago, according to The Associated Press.

"Northern Illinois was the hardest-hit area, accounting for nearly 75% of the 340,000 power outages across the Midwest Tuesday morning in the wake of the storms. Camp Grove, Illinois, clocked a 105-mph wind gust as the storms blitzed the region, wind speeds commonly found in the core of a Category 2 hurricane."

Read more:

#ClimateChange #ClimateJustice
https://www.democracynow.org/2024/7/19/headlines/uk_court_hands_4_and_5_year_prison_sentences_to_climate_activists_for_planning_nonviolent_protest

card.title: U.K. Court Hands 4- and 5-Year Prison Sentences to Climate Activists for Planning Nonviolent Protest
card.description:
A British court sentenced five climate activists to record four- and five-year prison terms for participating in a Zoom call to plan a peaceful protest on a major London highway in 2022. The activists, who are with the direct action group Just Stop Oil, were convicted of “conspiracy to cause a public nuisance” in a case which has triggered widespread outrage. Michel Forst, the U.N. special rapporteur on environmental defenders, warned, “This sentence should shock the conscience of any member of the public.” Meanwhile, Greenpeace UK said, “We’re giving a free hand to the polluting elite robbing us of a habitable planet while jailing those who’re trying to stop them.” Outside of the London courthouse, protesters gathered to support the activists, who have become known as the “Whole Truth Five,” as a van carted them off to prison. This is Just Stop Oil spokesperson Grahame Buss.

Grahame Buss: “We clearly do not live in a functioning democracy. A functioning democracy would be one in which we could act, in which we could make a change, in which we would be allowed to protest. The nonfunctioning democracy that we have is one in which oil companies and very wealthy people determine what our laws are, in which we get the chance to vote once every five years and it makes no bloody difference at all, where we see governments — a new government coming in with virtually the same policies as the one that went out. How can you talk about a functioning democracy when we are in a climate collapse and our government is not recognizing it and not protecting us? It’s absolutely disgraceful. It has to stop.”

content:
Because he begins his thread by pointing to Mauna Loa CO2 growth rate in 2023, I needed to check CO2 values from Cape Grim, #Tasmania. Because I had seen in winter that seismic activity around Mauna Loa had increased lots from November 2023 – and I was hoping that high CO2 values were just local outgassing from the volcanoes.

But the huge CO2 growth arrived at Cape Grim in January 2024, and also reached record high of 3.91 in June 2024. https://capegrim.csiro.au
(Cape Grim in the Southern Hemisphere is delayed in receiving the "updated" well-mixed greenhouse gases in their near-surface flasks.)

To also correlate growth rates to #ElNino and #LaNina episodes, I plotted #CO2 and #methane growth rates alongside sea surface temperature anomaly in the #Pacific region called "Nino3.4"
Top chart: CO2 growth is plotted in sync with El Nino 2015, meaning, I moved the monthly values 8 months earlier (mixing delay).
A clear correlation is evident.
What this also shows, I believe, is the hemispheric CO2 growth source, relative to the hemisphere that was the main source in Nino 2015.
CO2 growth earlier than a Nino episode like for instance 2023 means, the major CO2 source was close by so that the flask at Cape Grim received it earlier. The source was in the Southern Hemisphere.

But CO2 growth later than a Nino episode puts the source further away, ie Northern Hemisphere.

The other two charts show #CH4 growth (divided by 10) in Cape Grim. First, values moved 8 months earlier, next actual monthly values. I can detect no correlation at all with Nino Nina episodes.
(Disproving my earlier thinking that big CH4 growth goes in tandem with La Nina episodes when tropical wetlands receive much more rain. Gotta look into that again..)

That the land carbon sinks collapsed in 2023 is shocking. That climate models do not incorporate shrinking carbon sinks like the author states (see #1 above), is even more shocking.
What's typical: creative accounting by most countries, and the EU: they get to "net zero" by subtracting fictional land carbon sinks from their ongoing fossil emissions.
Fiction carbon sinks: their estimated values are far too high today, and even more so by 2050.

#FridaysForFuture #ClimateChange

media_attachments.description:
3 charts with monthly data from May 1976 to June 2024. All 3 charts show sea surface temperature anomaly for the Pacific region "Nino3.4". Top chart shows it with monthly CO2 growth in Cape Grim, Tasmania. Growth range is from 0 in 1981 to 3.99 in June 2024. In between, CO2 growth undulates and grows far more in Nino months and far less in months with cooler SST anomaly. 
CO2 values are plotted 8 months earlier than actual data. 

Bottom 2 charts show CH4 growth alongside SST anomaly in Nino3.4. CH4 growth is divided by 10. First chart is with growth values also plotted 8 months earlier and next chart with actual monthly values ( /10). No correlation with Nino can be detected in either chart. Growth values  go up and down and range from slightly negative in the early 2000 years, to +2 ppb (= 20ppb) in 1989 and 2022.

content:
It's difficult to comprehend the scope of the climate crisis in full. Each house, or town is a dot on the Earth, same as the "we are here" image of the tiny dot of Earth compared to the greater Universe.

Our brains are not capable of fully accessing the scope of this crisis and all its intricacies, but we can emulate it.

It involves taking in a larger picture, being a part of a bigger entity and looking through their/its eyes and feeling that connection.

To better understand the scope of climate change, we must look through the eyes of Earth and emulate it as a whole, feeling the damage and pain being caused.

Official institutions think in terms of "my country", "my city", "my town". This view is very narrow. They cannot "see" the urgency of the situation, and are unwilling to even try.

Climate change is a slow erosion of life as we know it and we must encompass it fully. There is no "fixing it" if you can only see your little piece of land.

#ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis

content:
🌳 Wow! Trees. 🥰

In a study published this week (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07592-w) trees have been found to play a vital role in removing the #greenhousegas methane from the atmosphere!

We knew trees remove CO2 but the University of Birmingham-led study has found that microbes in bark also absorb methane.

It’s estimated that this makes trees 10% more beneficial for negating #climatechange than previously thought.

THREE CHEERS FOR THE TREES…
🌴🌲🌳🥳

card.title: Global atmospheric methane uptake by upland tree woody surfaces - Nature
card.description: Studies of in situ woody surface methane exchange in upland tropical, temperate and boreal forest trees find that methane uptake can result in a net tree methane sink that is globally significant and demonstrates an additional climate benefit provided by trees.

card.title: Big Data in the Critical Zone: Deciphering Controls on Hydro-Biogeochemical Processes Across Scales
card.description: Extending from the top of the canopy to the bottom of circulating groundwater, the Critical Zone (CZ) is shaped by a myriad of hydro-biogeochemical processes. Historically, the long-term and/or large-scale drivers of these processes have remained poorly understood due to data limitations. The increasing availability of CZ data, including datasets that span multiple sites, years, variables, and/or disciplines, has created new possibilities for uncovering CZ processes. “Big data” approaches including machine learning and deep learning can help elucidate controls on surface and subsurface processes across large environmental gradients and illustrate how CZ processes respond to changing climate and land use. Furthermore, such novel techniques enable analysis across large spatiotemporal scales. We welcome contributions that employ a variety of innovative methods including machine learning, deep learning, or other statistical approaches to understand CZ processes using large datasets, particularly using interdisciplinary or cross-disciplinary approaches.

content:
Erin Seybold is a Cluster member based at the University of Kansas and a co-convener of the American Geophysical Union 2024 Annual Fall meeting session 'Frontiers in Water Quality'.

Seybold encourages scientists at the early stages of their careers, including undergraduate students, to propose abstracts.

Seybold says conveners like herself want to uplift those voices on the big platform of the AGU24 meeting.

Frontiers in #WaterQuality 🔗📝: https://bit.ly/FrontiersInWaterQuality

#science #ClimateChange

card.title: Frontiers in Water Quality
card.description: Water quality science is at the nexus of physical, biological, and chemical processes that occur across a range of spatial and temporal scales. The uncertain impact of anthropogenic climate and land use change on water quality has spurred researchers to develop, apply, and test novel hypotheses and models. As a result, the frontier of water quality science has seen significant advancement in field-based, laboratory, and computational domains – as well as research that cuts across these fields. In this session, we intend to highlight emerging insights that help explain water quality variation through space and time. In particular, we welcome abstracts that tackle problems which span spatial scales, from local to global, and temporal variability, from sub-hourly to decadal. Further, we encourage submissions that apply process-based, machine learning, and/or hybrid approaches toward unraveling the drivers of water quality.

➡️ https://climatejustice.social/@breadandcircuses/112852799636584192

Now here’s another example of the oil industry lying in order to protect their profits. They know “carbon capture and storage” (CCS) does not work. They know it is *not* a valid climate solution — and yet they just keep on promoting it, keep on selling that spurious idea to regulators and to the public.

Capitalists always lie.

➡️ https://www.vox.com/climate/363076/climate-change-solution-shell-exxon-mobil-carbon-capture

The fossil fuel industry's carbon capture bamboozle, explained." Below this is a photo of a coal-burning power plant next to a CCS plant near Houston, Texas.

card.title: Bread and Circuses (@breadandcircuses@climatejustice.social)
card.description:
Attached: 1 image

Guess what. The plastic industry (also known as the oil industry) is spending millions of dollars lying to you in ads about "advanced recycling" which doesn't work...
__________________________

If you’ve tuned into any major TV network in the last few months, you may have seen an ad promising a brand new way to end plastic pollution: advanced recycling. 

So far, America’s Plastic Makers has spent nearly $30 million since 2023 to place ads touting “advanced recycling” and other sustainability measures.

These ads are not trying to sell products. They’re trying to sell consumers a utopian idea: that plastic consumption can continue as is, without irreparably damaging public health and the planet.
__________________________

FULL STORY -- https://heated.world/p/the-plastic-industrys-30-million

#Science #Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #Capitalism #Greenwashing

content:
Open letter to Degrowthers:

There is increasing frustration among degrowth activists that the general trend of the degrowth movement remains heavily European-centered, and overly academic. Thousands of degrowth activists struggle in the shadows of capitalism to contribute to the movement, while having to make ends meet on little income, or no income whatsoever. Recognition for effort remains strongly coupled with academic status, seniority or popularity. In a true egalitarian movement, merit and status would have no place, and would be recognized for what they really are: delusional creations of society.

5 proposals:

  1. Decouple status from merit
  2. Create a solidarity fund
  3. "Make proactive efforts to engage with the working class, indigenous peoples, environmental activists, and people of the majority world. Invite participants to degrowth conferences by financing their participation in person, or remotely, through the Solidarity Fund."
  4. Support solidarity within the movement
  5. "Create or support boots-on-the-ground missions of paid activists that would engage with the working class, indigenous people, environmental activists, people of the Global South, and local communities."

Presented by Félix Garnier at the Pontevedra Conference on June 19th 2024

#Degrowth #AntiCapitalism #Capitalism #ClimateChange #ClimateResilience

https://www.resilience.org/stories/2024-07-10/degrowthers-of-the-world-unite-a-proposal-for-degrowth-academics-activists-and-practitioners-to-join-forces-as-equals/

card.title: Degrowthers of the World, Unite: A proposal for degrowth academics, activists, and practitioners to join forces as equals - resilience

content:
Plants and their pollinators are increasingly out of sync.

"As global temps rise and seasons shift, bees and other pollinators are missing critical connections with flowers and crops."

We've removed ecological complexity. Ancient diverse forests or woodlands, species rich grasslands or plains, cleared for monocultures.

https://grist.org/food-and-agriculture/plants-and-their-pollinators-are-increasingly-out-of-sync/

Our chance of climate resilience is to power-down now, & let ecological complexity return.

#climatecrisis #climatechange #nature #wellbeingeconomy
